answer_html: Thus if \(\displaystyle \alpha + 1 = 3\) we have that \(\displaystyle \alpha = 2\) which is as claimed in the question.
answer_latex:
Thus if
$\displaystyle \alpha + 1 = 3$ we have that $\displaystyle \alpha = 2$
which is as claimed in the question.
hints_html: Suppose a number has at least two distinct prime divisors. What is a lower bound on the number of divisors in this case?
hints_latex:
Suppose a number has at least two distinct prime divisors. What is a
lower bound on the number of divisors in this case?
hints_raw: Suppose a number has at least two distinct prime divisors. What is a lower bound on the number of divisors in this case?
sols_html:
The answer is true.

Suppose that n has at least two distinct positive divisors p and q. Then it has at least 4 prime divisors given by \(\displaystyle 1,p,q,pq\). Thus n must only have one prime divisor. Then if \(\displaystyle n = p^{\alpha}\), then n has \(\displaystyle \alpha +1\) prime divisors. Thus if \(\displaystyle \alpha + 1 = 3\) we have that \(\displaystyle \alpha = 2\) which is as claimed in the question.
sols_latex:
The answer is \textbf{true}.

Suppose that \emph{n} has at least two distinct positive divisors
\emph{p} and \emph{q}. Then it has at least 4 prime divisors given by
$\displaystyle 1,p,q,pq$. Thus \emph{n} must only have one prime
divisor. Then if $\displaystyle n = p^{\alpha}$, then \emph{n} has
$\displaystyle \alpha +1$ prime divisors. Thus if
$\displaystyle \alpha + 1 = 3$ we have that $\displaystyle \alpha = 2$
which is as claimed in the question.
sols_raw:
The answer is '''true'''. 

Suppose that ''n'' has at least two distinct positive divisors ''p'' and ''q''. Then it has at least 4 prime divisors given by <math> \displaystyle 1,p,q,pq</math>. Thus ''n'' must only have one prime divisor. Then if <math> \displaystyle n = p^{\alpha} </math>, then ''n'' has <math> \displaystyle \alpha +1</math> prime divisors. Thus if <math> \displaystyle \alpha + 1 = 3</math> we have that <math> \displaystyle \alpha = 2</math> which is as claimed in the question.
statement_html:
True or False

Suppose that n is an integer with exactly 3 possible divisors. Then \(n = p^2\) for some prime p.
statement_raw:
'''True or False'''

Suppose that ''n'' is an integer with exactly 3 possible divisors. Then <math> n = p^2</math> for some prime ''p''.
